executive_summary: The Forklift Manufacturing industry primarily manufactures forklifts, also known as industrial trucks, which are small- to midsize material-handling vehicles used to lift and carry heavy loads from one location to another. Forklifts are mainly used by construction, manufacturing and freight-handling industries. Growth in these industries underpins demand for forklifts produced by manufacturers. Revenue growth has been stunted overall because of suspended trade and industrial production activity amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Many companies suspended their operations temporarily because of government restrictions. Still, restrictions have substantially eased, enabling activity within the industrial production sector to resume. Still, industry revenue has been shrinking at a CAGR of 0.6% through the end of 2024 to reach $12.9 billion, including an expected dip of 0.7% in 2024 alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Business investment in machinery and increased industrial production drove demand for forklifts used in manufacturing. Booming utility construction helped to shore up demand for forklifts used in construction. Increased demand from wholesalers and retailers catering to the increased needs of e-commerce sales helped drive demand for materials handling equipment used in storage, transportation and logistics. However, investment in new machinery and equipment was put on hold or canceled during the COVID-19 pandemic due to social distancing measures, hindering demand from downstream markets and draining revenue.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Competition From Abroad Is Impeding Domestic Growth
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: A strong US Dollar has depressed sales to overseas export markets. Still, exports to USMCA trade partners have swelled beyond pre-pandemic levels, accounting for an expected combined 69.6% of all forklift exports. Trade frictions between the United States and China have resulted in exports falling. Still, lower production costs in China, Japan and Germany have made imported goods more attractive, increasing import penetration and competition.
To battle persistently high inflation rates across the US Economy, the Federal Reserve announced that they would conduct contractionary monetary policy

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: THE INFRASTRUCTURE INVESTMENT AND JOBS ACT
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The passage of the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act (IIJA) has already begun to benefit manufacturers. Bulk orders have been placed as construction companies gear up to work on infrastructure projects. These projects are expected to take years to complete, ensuring sustained need from construction markets. Beyond the initial investments, manufacturers can look forward to long-term growth opportunities by maintaining and repairing existing equipment and building solid relationships with construction companies.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: DOWNSTREAM MARKETS WILL IMPROVE AND EXPAND
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Forklift manufacturers benefit from more robust demand from its major downstream markets, including freight and transportation, manufacturing, construction, mining and retail. US manufacturing, wholesale and retail companies will devote significant resources to improving inventory management to better compete.

The push to increase battery life efficiency and reduce emissions through hybrid vehicles has dominated the industry's lift truck manufacturers. It will continue to be a significant selling point. Technological innovations are designed to attract business by reducing ongoing operating and maintenance costs that occur after purchase, though it is more expensive at the point of purchase.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: INTERNATIONAL CONFLICTS AND A DEPRECIATING US DOLLAR WILL BOOST EXPORTS
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: High inflation has weakened the strength of the US Dollar on the international stage. This will likely lead to increased demand from export markets, particularly from USMCA trade partners. European countries have placed an embargo on Russian-produced goods in response to the ongoing Russo-Ukrainian War. While most of this demand has been filled by Germany, the region's largest manufactured goods producer, it has opened these markets to US imports to fill the gaps. This trend will likely be exasperated as the war continues.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: GROWTH ON THE HORIZON THANKS TO THE IIJA
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The industry will likely expand as projects funded by the Infrastructure Investment & Jobs Act take shape in the coming years. Massive construction projects will require forklifts for day-to-day operations. This steady income stream from construction markets will help forklift manufacturers establish long-standing relationships with customers and

industry_definition: Companies in this industry primarily manufacture forklifts, which are also known as industrial trucks. Forklifts include truck-type and hand-type pallet movers, skid jacks and portable stackers. Forklifts can load material and transport it over short distances and are used heavily in the construction, manufacturing and freight logistics sectors. This industry's operations also include the manufacture and sale of parts and attachments for forklifts.

positive_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level high - increasing

opportunities: High Performance Drivers - Industrial production index

key_trends: Purchase costs form a basis of competition. Internal competition is based primarily on the strength and quality of dealers, brand loyalty, after-sale service, price, performance, quality, cost of ownership over the lift truck's useful life
Competition from inexpensive imports poses the biggest threat
Import penetration has risen as international manufacturers capitalize on lower labor costs and operational efficiencies, enabling lower prices for foreign products
The industry weathered rising interest rates
Revenue slumped slightly thanks to expanding nonresidential markets, which mitigated the loss from depressed needs in residential construction markets
Machines and production are becoming more efficient as technology advances
The heavy equipment and tools used by companies are reducing costs and allowing for profit to expand
Savvy manufacturers will be able to capitalize on the implementation of the IIJA (Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act) in the coming years
The IIJA spending package has allotted $1.2 trillion to constructing and maintaining new and existing infrastructure, leading to a surge in demand
Competition rises in line with the needs of the construction sector
Manufacturing companies are introducing new advanced electrical machinery
The push to reduce carbon emissions is forcing companies to upgrade their equipment
The Clean Air Act is raising costs
The US Environmental Protection Agency is attempting to reduce the emission of air pollutants from manufacturing companies
Tariffs on foreign suppliers enable domestic manufacturers to compete
Inflated prices on foreign goods are designed to closely match the costs faced by US companies

market_segmentation.segment_description: Such industries include food and beverage companies, durable goods manufacturers and other consumer goods producers. Consumer industries account for the largest share of downstream markets for the Forklift Manufacturing industry.

Manufacturing industries use forklifts extensively in their warehouses to store and retrieve inventory. Demand from this segment moves in line with the industrial production index and manufacturing capacity utilization, which rely on downstream consumer demand.
Freight-handling industries use industrial trucks and forklift equipment to move freight within warehouses, making forklift equipment a vital component of the supply chain.
Other industries serviced by the industry include construction, natural resource extraction and rental sectors. Construction industries use forklifts to position and move materials on job sites.

products_and_services.product_description: This segment includes Class 4 and 5 forklifts where the driver sits during operation. These are the type of trucks most people associate with forklifts.

This segment includes Class 3 products with solid tires. While shipments of Class 3 products have grown steadily, they have fallen as a share of total shipments thanks to a dramatic spike in demand for other products.

Electric rider trucks include a combination of Class 1 and 2 industrial trucks with pneumatic or solid tires. While gas-powered forklifts have fallen in popularity, this segment has risen slightly as a share of shipments.

tier_1_buyers: Transportation and Warehousing in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Construction projects, like office buildings, industrial facilities, hotels, airports and seaports, generate the need for forklifts and related equipment. Industry forklifts are used not only during construction but also afterward for moving and storing heavy equipment and inventory.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Manufacturers Compete with Low-Cost Goods from Foreign Countries
international_trade_points.trade_description: China and Japan provide low-cost substitute goods since these countries have lower labor costs. This attracts downstream US buyers who purchase products in bulk, justifying import costs.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Escalating Tensions with China Limit Imports
international_trade_points.trade_description: Chinese-produced forklifts carry a lower per-unit cost than US-manufactured ones. However, escalating political tensions have seeped into the private

international_trade_points.trade_title: Appreciating Dollar and Rising Steel and Oil Prices Hinders Exports
international_trade_points.trade_description: The appreciation of the US dollar relative to the currencies of major trading partners makes domestic goods more expensive and, therefore, less appealing.

business_locations.location: THE GREAT LAKES AND ITS CLOSE DOWNSTREAM MANUFACTURERS
business_locations.location_description: The Great Lakes region has been a historically dominant epicenter for manufacturing in the US. Forklift manufacturers flock to this region because of its high concentration of upstream raw material suppliers and its popularity with downstream manufacturing markets.

business_locations.location: Low Taxes Draw Manufacturers to the Southeast
business_locations.location_description: The Southeast has a high population and low labor costs. Manufacturers specializing in industrial trucks, tractors, trailers and stacker products flock to this region to appeal to downstream manufacturers and warehouses that capitalize on these demographic trends.

business_locations.location: Mineral Mining Attracts Manufacturers to the Plains
business_locations.location_description: The Plains region is heavily invested in mining and industrial activities. Manufacturers specializing in industrial truck and overhead crane products concentrate here to appeal to these markets and reduce transportation costs.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) limits the pollution emitted from the manufacturing process. Manufacturers of lift trucks, forklifts and other engine-powered vehicles must comply with EPA regulations and local and state governments, which raises costs.

29 CFR 1910.178(a) is just one of the many regulations manufacturers must follow strictly to participate in the industry. This regulation, in particular, contains safety requirements surrounding fire protection, design and maintenance when manufacturing forklifts.

The Department of Transportation (DOT) outlines strict regulations that manufacturers must conform to when producing forklifts. These rules include energy efficiency standards, product dimensions and weight limits, proper documentation and load securement.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry is mature, indicating high barriers.
The industry has high revenue volatility.
The industry has low and steady assistance level.
The industry has high and increasing globalization.
The industry has high and steady competition level.

basis_points.basis_description: Purchase costs form a basis of competition.
Internal competition is based on dealer strength, brand loyalty, after-sale service, price, performance, quality, and cost of ownership.
Competition from inexpensive imports poses the biggest threat due to lower labor costs and operational efficiencies.

concentration_points.concentration_description: It's challenging to enter due to high capital investment required, driving away competition. Top brands have established name, product range and best technologies.
The industry remains relatively unconcentrated as top companies can only produce a few products cost-effectively, allowing niche companies to fill gaps.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Material purchases are by far the most significant expense incurred by this industry.
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Input costs, particularly for steel and rubber, are difficult for manufacturers to pass down to consumers because of their volatility.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: The primary raw material US forklift manufacturers purchased is steel.
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Steel is ideal for forklift manufacturing because of its strength and durability.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Successful forklift manufacturers depend heavily on skilled laborers and engineers to design the products and create technology packages.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Most revenue relies upon downstream demand from other parts of the economy, including mining, freight, construction and manufacturing.
volatility_points.volatility_description: To counter this, manufacturers invest in technological improvements, design advancements and lower prices to help boost demand when it might otherwise sink.

volatility_points.volatility_title: The industry is sensitive to trends in both global economic conditions and exchange rates since domestic companies rely on other countries products, including steel and crude oil.
volatility_points.volatility_description: Appreciation of the US dollar has made domestic goods more expensive for foreigners and has led to a decrease in exports which lowers industry revenue and demand.

volatility_points.volatility_title: The economic impact of COVID-19 caused forklift manufacturing revenue to fall as demand for industry products fell, though it's anticipated to bounce back over the coming years.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: To reduce and avoid carbon emission, manufacturing companies are switching to electrically powered machines.
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: These machines are more expensive, but due to the increased efficiency they provide, companies have been able to save on cost in the long-run.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Manufacturers have invested in developing specialized products for emerging export markets, like lower-usage electric lift trucks.
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Improved automation technology has created further demand from the agricultural sector.

FAQs.question: How is your company affected by imports?
FAQs.answer: Imports increase competition significantly for domestic operators.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: Company sales are incredibly dependent on general business and macroeconomic trends.

FAQs.question: Is your company located near important suppliers?
FAQs.answer: Being in proximity to suppliers is of significant importance to industry operators.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: Companies in this industry have been subject to volatile input prices over the past five years.

FAQs.question: How is your company leveraging new technology such as RFID tags?
FAQs.answer: Companies in this industry that implement RFID tags are more efficient in tracking operations in real time.

FAQs.question: Do you use SAP software systems to optimize all aspects of your company's manufacturing, sales, inventory and distribution channels?
FAQs.answer: Maintaining SAP operations is of paramount importance for the largest companies in this industry.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: Companies in this industry must aim to adhere to all regulatory protocols and train all employees adequately to ensure all health and safety standards are met.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly impacted profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: This industry is not heavily regulated.

FAQs.question: How has input price volatility affected profit margins over the past 12 months?
FAQs.answer: Profit margins are significantly affected by the price of steel.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: This industry has a medium level of concentration with the largest players being able to garner the highest profit.

FAQs.question: How do you stay up to date on environmental regulations? Have you had issues with compliance in the past?
FAQs.answer: Manufacturers experience a range of regulations regarding the generation and disposal of hazardous wastes. Failure to meet compliance can increase operating costs.

FAQs.question: What systems do you have in place to keep product quality high? Do you incorporate customer feedback?
FAQs.answer: The ability to control quality and minimize faulty products reaching the market will help increase brand loyalty through perceived reliability.

FAQs.question: How close are you to downstream construction and export markets? How do you keep order turnarounds tight?
FAQs.answer: Successful manufacturers locate close to raw material deposits and the main sources of demand.

FAQs.question: How have steel price fluctuations affected profitability?
FAQs.answer: Changes in the price of inputs, such as steel, affect the industry's profitability.

FAQs.question: What can you do to keep revenue steady?
How much of your sales come from exports? Can you pursue new leads in foreign markets as the dollar depreciates?
FAQs.answer: As the value of the dollar falls, it leads to lower relative export prices and higher relative import prices, bolstering industry revenue.

FAQs.question: Do you have strong relationships in construction markets? How can you competitively angle your products for construction companies?
FAQs.answer: Construction projects, such as office buildings, industrial facilities, hotels, airports and seaports, generate demand for forklifts and related equipment.
